article.title: Spatial omics technologies at multimodal and single cell/subcellular level
funding: Leukemia and Lymphoma Society (LLS) grants (MCL7001-18, LLS 9238-16, LLS-MCL7001-18)
National Institutes of Health (R01MH117406, R01AI151059, R01AI158676, R01CA249054, R01AI161444)
article.abstract: Spatial omics technologies enable a deeper understanding of cellular organizations and interactions within a tissue of interest.

sections.introduction: Spatial omics technologies enable a deeper understanding of cellular organizations and interactions within a tissue of interest. These assays can identify specific compartments or regions in a tissue with differential transcript or protein abundance, delineate their interactions, and complement other methods in defining cellular phenotypes.
sections.methods: Methods for molecular profiling of single cells in situ, within their native spatial context, are rapidly developing.

article.insights_summary: Spatial omics technologies enable a deeper understanding of cellular organizations and interactions within a tissue of interest. These assays can identify specific compartments or regions in a tissue with differential transcript or protein abundance, delineate their interactions, and complement other methods in defining cellular phenotypes.
article.acknowledgments: We would like to thank the Scientific Computing Unit (SCU) and funding from the WorldQuant Foundation, NASA (NNH18ZTT001N-FG2, 80NSSC22K0254), the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society (LLS) grants (MCL7001-18, LLS 9238-16, LLS-MCL7001-18), and the National Institutes of Health (R01MH117406, R01AI151059, R01AI158676, R01CA249054, R01AI161444).
